events.name: Controls
events.comment: The Controls global is a string indicator that defines the control-type used in the main game loop. By default, a computer will be set on Keyboard unless a button is pressed on a connected gamepad. The Touch controls are the only controls available on a mobile device. They can also be turned on (under the name "visual controls" in the options on a PC.)

events.title: Basic movements
events.description: All the codes for the Player's basic movements: move, jump and using a mean of transportation. Other controls can be found in the Fight controls or Meta controls groups.

children.text: Player stats.

children.name: Speed
children.comment: The Speed variable represents the amount of pixels traversed by a single move from the Player. It can be changed by using various means of transportation such as the Skateboard, for example.

children.title: Means of Transportation
children.description: All the codes related to the various means of transportation's effects.

children.text: Skateboard

children.title: Control-type logic
children.description: All the codes which defines the Controls global variable. In the beginning, the program verifies whether the game is running from a mobile device. If not, the game stays in Keyboard unless a Gamepad button is pressed twice. To swap between Keyboard and Gamepad thus uses this double press techniques.

children.text: This part runs a series of checks to determine if the game is running on mobile.
This makes the visual gamepad invisible if the game is not run with the Touch control-type.
I need to add an option to make it visible on PC.
If the control-type is not Touch, allows the swapping mechanic to endure.
The basic movements require an "active" player. Some moves and situations (like free fall) might make a Player inactive and thus unable to use the following controls.

children.title: Keyboard & Gamepad
children.description: All the codes for the Keyboard and Gamepad control-types. Since both are extremely similar, they have been regrouped.

children.text: Basic directional movement begins with a VerifyMovePossibility function which checks for adjacent obstacles. Using a preliminary function allowed me to trigger part (but not all) effects related to a movement even if that movement, in the end, wouldn't be triggered due to an obstacle. The most obvious example of this is the redirection of the Player's weapon which must happen regardless of whether the Player actually moves or not when one of the movement key is pressed. This system is the same for the Gamepad.
Move

actions.text: The two parameters of the function will be used to identify the movement's cardinal direction.

children.text: Using this secondary check, we can allow the function to loop if a movement key is to be maintained down.
The rest is the same for other keys.
Jump
Attack
Interact
Skateboard
This is the same code as the Keyboard, but with Gamepad inputs.
Move
Jump
Attack

Skateboard
Cancel Skateboard

children.title: Touch
children.description: All the codes for the Touch control-type. This code functions a bit differently from the Keyboard and Gamepad group.

children.text: In this control-type, gestures are regrouped under Taps or Touches.

children.title: Taps
children.description: All the codes pertaining to the tap gestures.

children.text: Move
Depending on the value which the Type variable of the TouchZone object has, triggers the VerifyMovePossibility as explained in the Keyboard & Gamepad group.
For Jump and Attack, the animation of the UI_AB_Button is defined by the Type variable of the tapped TouchZone.
The functions and mechanics leading to them are similar to the previous control types and should be self explanatory.
Jump
Attack.

children.title: Touches
children.description: All the codes pertaining to the touches gestures.

children.text: The second half of the movement component (the holding down of the visual gamepad) is defined in the following part of the code. It should be reminescent of the previous control-types, the main difference is that the "press" and "hold" components of the Player movement have been split between their respective touch gestures here.
Skateboard
Cancel Skateboard
